paper_title.ja: 現職教員の中・高等学校生物教育に対する認識と展望ーSPP研修参加者のアンケート調査よりー
paper_title.en: The Present Realization and Future Perspective of Biology Education among Junior and Senior High School Teachers : From the Results of Questionnaires Conducted during SPP Training Courses on Recombinant DNA

description.ja: We held recombinant DNA course for junior and senior high school teachers four times from 2002 through 2003, after the MEXT issued new guidelines regarding recombinant DNA experiments for educational purposes. We used the Biotechnology Explorer kit (Bio-Rad), with which the participants would be able to conduct recombinant DNA experiments in their own schools. We assigned a written test to the participants before (pre-test) and after (post-test) the course, and analyzed their understanding of the lectures and experiments. We also gathered information by questionnaires from the participants, analyzed it, and came to the following conclusions. 1) Participants are dissatisfied with current biology textbooks. 2) Participants claim that the restrictions of the contents of science textbooks by the MEXT are unreasonable and that teachers should be allowed to teach according to their individual circumstances. 3) Participants claim that every high school student should learn DNA science and biotechnology as a part of science literacy. 4) DNA education in high schools is not easy to perform in the current situation because colleagues in schools and parents do not understand well the safety and importance of recombinant DNA technologies. We then discuss the present realization and future perspective of DNA education for high school biology.
description.en: We held recombinant DNA course for junior and senior high school teachers four times from 2002 through 2003, after the MEXT issued new guidelines regarding recombinant DNA experiments for educational purposes. We used the Biotechnology Explorer kit (Bio-Rad), with which the participants would be able to conduct recombinant DNA experiments in their own schools. We assigned a written test to the participants before (pre-test) and after (post-test) the course, and analyzed their understanding of the lectures and experiments. We also gathered information by questionnaires from the participants, analyzed it, and came to the following conclusions. 1) Participants are dissatisfied with current biology textbooks. 2) Participants claim that the restrictions of the contents of science textbooks by the MEXT are unreasonable and that teachers should be allowed to teach according to their individual circumstances. 3) Participants claim that every high school student should learn DNA science and biotechnology as a part of science literacy. 4) DNA education in high schools is not easy to perform in the current situation because colleagues in schools and parents do not understand well the safety and importance of recombinant DNA technologies. We then discuss the present realization and future perspective of DNA education for high school biology.

publication_name.ja: Bulletin of Tokyo Gakugei University Sect. (]G0004[)Mathematics and Natural Sciences

paper_title.en: RNA LEGO: Magnesium-dependent formation of specific RNA assemblies through kissing interactions

description.en: The high affinity and specificity of nucleic acid base complementarity has been proven to be a powerful method for constructing specific molecular assemblies. On the other hand, recent structural studies of RNA have revealed the wide range of tertiary interactions utilized in RNA folding, which may potentially be used as tools for the design of specific macromolecular assemblies. Here, RNA building blocks containing two hairpin loops, based on the dimerization initiation site (DIS) of HIV RNA, connected by a short linker were used to construct large RNA assemblies through hairpin loop-loop ("kissing") interactions. We show that specific linear and circular assemblies can be constructed in a magnesium-dependent manner using several non-self-complementary loop-loop interactions designed in this study. These results show that the use of RNA tertiary interactions may broaden the reportoire of nucleic acid-based nanostructures.
